analysis.validation.metricsÂ¶

Source: src\analysis\validation\metrics.py

Module OverviewÂ¶

Statistical and validation metrics for analysis systems.

Advanced Mathematical TheoryÂ¶

Validation MetricsÂ¶

Mean Squared Error (MSE):

\[\text{MSE} = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n (y_i - \hat{y}_i)^2\]

Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE):

\[\text{RMSE} = \sqrt{\text{MSE}}\]

Mean Absolute Error (MAE):

\[\text{MAE} = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n |y_i - \hat{y}_i|\]

Coefficient of DeterminationÂ¶

R-squared:

\[R^2 = 1 - \frac{\sum(y_i - \hat{y}_i)^2}{\sum(y_i - \bar{y})^2} = 1 - \frac{\text{SSE}}{\text{SST}}\]

Adjusted R-squared:

\[R_{adj}^2 = 1 - \frac{(1-R^2)(n-1)}{n-p-1}\]

Where \(p\) is number of predictors.

Normalized MetricsÂ¶

Normalized RMSE:

\[\text{NRMSE} = \frac{\text{RMSE}}{y_{max} - y_{min}} \times 100\%\]

Mean Absolute Percentage Error:

\[\text{MAPE} = \frac{100\%}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n \left|\frac{y_i - \hat{y}_i}{y_i}\right|\]

Theilâ€™s U StatisticÂ¶

Inequality coefficient:

\[U = \frac{\sqrt{\frac{1}{n}\sum(y_i - \hat{y}_i)^2}}{\sqrt{\frac{1}{n}\sum y_i^2} + \sqrt{\frac{1}{n}\sum \hat{y}_i^2}}\]

Range: \(U \in [0, 1]\), where 0 is perfect fit.

Tracking SignalÂ¶

Cumulative error:

\[\text{TS} = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^n (y_i - \hat{y}_i)}{\text{MAD}}\]

Where MAD is Mean Absolute Deviation.

Akaike Information Criterion (AIC)Â¶

Model selection criterion:

\[\text{AIC} = 2p - 2\ln(L)\]

Where \(p\) is parameters, \(L\) is likelihood.

Corrected AIC (small sample):

\[\text{AIC}_c = \text{AIC} + \frac{2p(p+1)}{n-p-1}\]

Architecture DiagramÂ¶

graph TD A[Predictions Å·] --> B[Error Computation] C[Actual y] --> B B --> D[MSE: 1/n Î£(y-Å·)Â²] B --> E[MAE: 1/n Î£|y-Å·|] B --> F[MAPE: 100/n Î£|y-Å·|/y] D --> G[RMSE: âˆšMSE] D --> H[RÂ²: 1-SSE/SST] G --> I{Normalize?} I -->|Yes| J[NRMSE] I -->|No| K[Absolute RMSE] H --> L{Adjust for p?} L -->|Yes| M[Adjusted RÂ²] L -->|No| N[Raw RÂ²] E --> O[Model Selection] F --> O J --> O K --> O M --> O N --> O O --> P[AIC/BIC] P --> Q[Best Model] style B fill:#9cf style O fill:#ff9 style Q fill:#9f9

Usage ExamplesÂ¶

Example 1: Basic AnalysisÂ¶

from src.analysis import Analyzer

# Initialize analyzer
analyzer = Analyzer(config)
result = analyzer.analyze(data)

Example 2: Statistical ValidationÂ¶

# Compute confidence intervals
from src.analysis.validation import compute_confidence_interval

ci = compute_confidence_interval(samples, confidence=0.95)
print(f"95% CI: [{ci.lower:.3f}, {ci.upper:.3f}]")

Example 3: Performance MetricsÂ¶

# Compute comprehensive metrics
from src.analysis.performance import compute_all_metrics

metrics = compute_all_metrics(
    time=t,
    state=x,
    control=u,
    reference=r
)
print(f"ISE: {metrics.ise:.2f}, ITAE: {metrics.itae:.2f}")

Example 4: Batch AnalysisÂ¶

# Analyze multiple trials
results = []
for trial in range(n_trials):
    result = run_simulation(trial_seed=trial)
    results.append(analyzer.analyze(result))

# Aggregate statistics
mean_performance = np.mean([r.performance for r in results])

Example 5: Robustness AnalysisÂ¶

# Parameter sensitivity analysis
from src.analysis.performance import sensitivity_analysis

sensitivity = sensitivity_analysis(
    system=plant,
    parameters={'mass': (0.8, 1.2), 'length': (0.9, 1.1)},
    metric=compute_stability_margin
)
print(f"Most sensitive: {sensitivity.most_sensitive_param}")

This module provides comprehensive metrics computation for validating control system performance, statistical analysis, and benchmarking.

Architecture DiagramÂ¶

graph TD A[Simulation Result] --> B[Time Vector t] A --> C[State Trajectory x_t_] A --> D[Control Signal u_t_] B --> E[Control Metrics] C --> E E --> F[ISE] E --> G[ITAE] E --> H[RMS Control] B --> I[Stability Metrics] C --> I I --> J[Overshoot] I --> K[Settling Time] I --> L[Damping Ratio] B --> M[Constraint Metrics] D --> M M --> N[Saturation Severity] M --> O[Violation Count] M --> P[Peak Violation] F --> Q[Metrics Dictionary] G --> Q H --> Q J --> Q K --> Q L --> Q N --> Q O --> Q P --> Q Q --> R[Validation Result] style E fill:#9cf style I fill:#fcf style M fill:#ff9 style Q fill:#f9f style R fill:#9f9

Data Flow:

  1. Extract time, state, control trajectories from simulation

  2. Control Metrics Module: Compute ISE, ITAE, RMS

  3. Stability Metrics Module: Compute overshoot, settling time, damping

  4. Constraint Metrics Module: Compute violations and severity

  5. Aggregate all metrics into unified dictionary

  6. Return structured validation result

Metric Categories:

  • Control Performance: Tracking accuracy, convergence speed

  • Stability Analysis: Overshoot, damping characteristics

  • Constraint Satisfaction: Actuator limits, physical constraints

Mathematical FoundationÂ¶

Performance Metric TheoryÂ¶

Rigorous performance metrics enable objective controller comparison and validation against specifications.

Control Engineering MetricsÂ¶

Integral of Time-weighted Absolute Error (ITAE):

\[ITAE = \int_0^T t |\vec{x}(t)| dt\]

  • Purpose: Penalizes long settling times

  • Property: Emphasizes late-time errors more than early errors

  • Interpretation: Lower ITAE â†’ faster convergence

Overshoot:

\[OS = \frac{\max(x(t)) - x_{\text{ref}}}{x_{\text{ref}}} \times 100\%\]

Damping Ratio (estimated from overshoot):

\[\zeta \approx \frac{-\ln(OS/100)}{\sqrt{\pi^2 + \ln^2(OS/100)}}\]

Constraint Violation AnalysisÂ¶

Saturation Severity:

\[SV = \int_0^T \max(0, |u(t)| - u_{\max}) dt\]

Violation Frequency:

\[VF = \frac{1}{T} \sum_{k=0}^{N} \mathbb{1}_{|u_k| > u_{\max}}\]

Peak Violation:

\[PV = \max_{t \in [0,T]} (|u(t)| - u_{\max})\]

Stability MetricsÂ¶

Lyapunov Exponent (numerical estimate):

\[\lambda = \lim_{T \to \infty} \frac{1}{T} \ln \frac{||\delta \vec{x}(T)||}{||\delta \vec{x}(0)||}\]

  • \(\lambda < 0\): Asymptotically stable

  • \(\lambda > 0\): Unstable (chaos)

Energy Dissipation Rate:

\[\dot{E} = \frac{dE}{dt} < 0 \quad \forall t > t_0\]

Required for Lyapunov stability.

Statistical PropertiesÂ¶

Consistency: Metrics should be monotonic in performance (better control â†’ lower ISE).

Sensitivity: Sufficient resolution to distinguish controller variants.

Robustness: Insensitive to numerical noise and discretization.

See: ../../../control_theory/performance_specifications

Complete Source CodeÂ¶

  1#======================================================================================\\\
  2#========================= src/analysis/validation/metrics.py =========================\\\
  3#======================================================================================\\\
  4
  5"""
  6Statistical and validation metrics for analysis systems.
  7
  8This module provides comprehensive metrics computation for validating
  9control system performance, statistical analysis, and benchmarking.
 10"""
 11
 12from typing import Dict, List, Tuple, Any, Optional
 13import numpy as np
 14from scipy import stats
 15import warnings
 16
 17
 18def compute_basic_metrics(data: np.ndarray) -> Dict[str, float]:
 19    """
 20    Compute basic statistical metrics for data analysis.
 21
 22    Args:
 23        data: Input data array
 24
 25    Returns:
 26        Dictionary containing basic statistical metrics
 27    """
 28    if len(data) == 0:
 29        return {
 30            'mean': 0.0,
 31            'std': 0.0,
 32            'min': 0.0,
 33            'max': 0.0,
 34            'median': 0.0,
 35            'count': 0
 36        }
 37
 38    return {
 39        'mean': float(np.mean(data)),
 40        'std': float(np.std(data)),
 41        'min': float(np.min(data)),
 42        'max': float(np.max(data)),
 43        'median': float(np.median(data)),
 44        'count': len(data)
 45    }
 46
 47
 48def compute_performance_metrics(
 49    reference: np.ndarray,
 50    actual: np.ndarray
 51) -> Dict[str, float]:
 52    """
 53    Compute performance metrics comparing actual vs reference data.
 54
 55    Args:
 56        reference: Reference/target data
 57        actual: Actual measured data
 58
 59    Returns:
 60        Dictionary containing performance metrics
 61    """
 62    if len(reference) != len(actual):
 63        raise ValueError("Reference and actual data must have same length")
 64
 65    if len(reference) == 0:
 66        return {'mse': 0.0, 'rmse': 0.0, 'mae': 0.0, 'max_error': 0.0}
 67
 68    error = actual - reference
 69    mse = float(np.mean(error**2))
 70    rmse = float(np.sqrt(mse))
 71    mae = float(np.mean(np.abs(error)))
 72    max_error = float(np.max(np.abs(error)))
 73
 74    return {
 75        'mse': mse,
 76        'rmse': rmse,
 77        'mae': mae,
 78        'max_error': max_error
 79    }
 80
 81
 82def compute_control_metrics(
 83    control_signals: np.ndarray,
 84    time_vector: Optional[np.ndarray] = None
 85) -> Dict[str, float]:
 86    """
 87    Compute control-specific performance metrics.
 88
 89    Args:
 90        control_signals: Control input signals over time
 91        time_vector: Optional time vector for time-based metrics
 92
 93    Returns:
 94        Dictionary containing control metrics
 95    """
 96    if len(control_signals) == 0:
 97        return {
 98            'control_effort': 0.0,
 99            'max_control': 0.0,
100            'control_variation': 0.0,
101            'settling_time': 0.0
102        }
103
104    # Basic control metrics
105    control_effort = float(np.sum(np.abs(control_signals)))
106    max_control = float(np.max(np.abs(control_signals)))
107
108    # Control variation (total variation)
109    if len(control_signals) > 1:
110        control_variation = float(np.sum(np.abs(np.diff(control_signals))))
111    else:
112        control_variation = 0.0
113
114    # Settling time estimation (time to reach within 5% of final value)
115    settling_time = 0.0
116    if time_vector is not None and len(time_vector) == len(control_signals):
117        final_value = control_signals[-1]
118        tolerance = 0.05 * abs(final_value) if abs(final_value) > 1e-10 else 0.05
119
120        # Find last time control signal was outside tolerance
121        for i in range(len(control_signals) - 1, -1, -1):
122            if abs(control_signals[i] - final_value) > tolerance:
123                settling_time = float(time_vector[min(i + 1, len(time_vector) - 1)])
124                break
125
126    return {
127        'control_effort': control_effort,
128        'max_control': max_control,
129        'control_variation': control_variation,
130        'settling_time': settling_time
131    }
132
133
134def compute_stability_metrics(
135    states: np.ndarray,
136    reference_state: Optional[np.ndarray] = None
137) -> Dict[str, float]:
138    """
139    Compute stability-related metrics for state trajectories.
140
141    Args:
142        states: State trajectory matrix (time x state_dim)
143        reference_state: Optional reference state for deviation metrics
144
145    Returns:
146        Dictionary containing stability metrics
147    """
148    if len(states) == 0:
149        return {
150            'max_deviation': 0.0,
151            'final_deviation': 0.0,
152            'stability_margin': 0.0,
153            'lyapunov_estimate': 0.0
154        }
155
156    if reference_state is None:
157        reference_state = np.zeros(states.shape[1])
158
159    # Deviation from reference
160    deviations = states - reference_state
161    deviation_norms = np.linalg.norm(deviations, axis=1)
162
163    # Handle NaN values gracefully (use nanmax to ignore NaN)
164    max_deviation = float(np.nanmax(deviation_norms))
165    final_deviation = float(np.nanmax([deviation_norms[-1], 0.0]))  # Handle NaN in final value
166
167    # If all values are NaN, return safe defaults
168    if np.isnan(max_deviation):
169        max_deviation = 0.0
170    if np.isnan(final_deviation):
171        final_deviation = 0.0
172
173    # Simple stability margin (inverse of max deviation)
174    stability_margin = 1.0 / (1.0 + max_deviation)
175
176    # Rough Lyapunov exponent estimate
177    lyapunov_estimate = 0.0
178    if len(deviation_norms) > 10:
179        # Use log of deviation growth
180        nonzero_deviations = deviation_norms[deviation_norms > 1e-12]
181        if len(nonzero_deviations) > 5:
182            log_deviations = np.log(nonzero_deviations)
183            if len(log_deviations) > 1:
184                lyapunov_estimate = float(np.mean(np.diff(log_deviations)))
185
186    return {
187        'max_deviation': max_deviation,
188        'final_deviation': final_deviation,
189        'stability_margin': stability_margin,
190        'lyapunov_estimate': lyapunov_estimate
191    }
192
193
194def compute_frequency_metrics(
195    signal: np.ndarray,
196    sampling_rate: float,
197    frequency_bands: Optional[List[Tuple[float, float]]] = None
198) -> Dict[str, Any]:
199    """
200    Compute frequency domain metrics for signal analysis.
201
202    Args:
203        signal: Input signal
204        sampling_rate: Sampling rate in Hz
205        frequency_bands: Optional list of (low, high) frequency bands
206
207    Returns:
208        Dictionary containing frequency domain metrics
209    """
210    if len(signal) < 2:
211        return {
212            'dominant_frequency': 0.0,
213            'bandwidth': 0.0,
214            'power_spectrum': np.array([]),
215            'frequencies': np.array([])
216        }
217
218    # Compute power spectral density
219    frequencies = np.fft.fftfreq(len(signal), 1/sampling_rate)
220    fft_signal = np.fft.fft(signal)
221    power_spectrum = np.abs(fft_signal)**2
222
223    # Only consider positive frequencies
224    positive_freq_idx = frequencies >= 0
225    frequencies = frequencies[positive_freq_idx]
226    power_spectrum = power_spectrum[positive_freq_idx]
227
228    # Find dominant frequency
229    if len(power_spectrum) > 0:
230        dominant_freq_idx = np.argmax(power_spectrum)
231        dominant_frequency = float(frequencies[dominant_freq_idx])
232    else:
233        dominant_frequency = 0.0
234
235    # Estimate bandwidth (90% power)
236    total_power = np.sum(power_spectrum)
237    cumulative_power = np.cumsum(power_spectrum)
238
239    if total_power > 0:
240        # Find frequencies where cumulative power is 5% and 95%
241        low_idx = np.argmax(cumulative_power >= 0.05 * total_power)
242        high_idx = np.argmax(cumulative_power >= 0.95 * total_power)
243        bandwidth = float(frequencies[high_idx] - frequencies[low_idx])
244    else:
245        bandwidth = 0.0
246
247    # Compute power in frequency bands if specified
248    band_power = {}
249    if frequency_bands:
250        for i, (low, high) in enumerate(frequency_bands):
251            band_mask = (frequencies >= low) & (frequencies <= high)
252            band_power[f'band_{i}_power'] = float(np.sum(power_spectrum[band_mask]))
253
254    result = {
255        'dominant_frequency': dominant_frequency,
256        'bandwidth': bandwidth,
257        'power_spectrum': power_spectrum,
258        'frequencies': frequencies,
259        **band_power
260    }
261
262    return result
263
264
265def compute_statistical_significance(
266    data1: np.ndarray,
267    data2: np.ndarray,
268    test_type: str = 'ttest'
269) -> Dict[str, float]:
270    """
271    Compute statistical significance between two data sets.
272
273    Args:
274        data1: First data set
275        data2: Second data set
276        test_type: Type of statistical test ('ttest', 'mannwhitney', 'ks')
277
278    Returns:
279        Dictionary containing test statistics and p-value
280    """
281    if len(data1) == 0 or len(data2) == 0:
282        return {'statistic': 0.0, 'p_value': 1.0, 'significant': False}
283
284    try:
285        if test_type == 'ttest':
286            statistic, p_value = stats.ttest_ind(data1, data2)
287        elif test_type == 'mannwhitney':
288            statistic, p_value = stats.mannwhitneyu(data1, data2, alternative='two-sided')
289        elif test_type == 'ks':
290            statistic, p_value = stats.ks_2samp(data1, data2)
291        else:
292            raise ValueError(f"Unknown test type: {test_type}")
293
294        significant = p_value < 0.05  # Standard significance level
295
296        return {
297            'statistic': float(statistic),
298            'p_value': float(p_value),
299            'significant': bool(significant)
300        }
301
302    except Exception as e:
303        warnings.warn(f"Statistical test failed: {e}")
304        return {'statistic': 0.0, 'p_value': 1.0, 'significant': False}
305
306
307def compute_robustness_metrics(
308    nominal_performance: Dict[str, float],
309    perturbed_performances: List[Dict[str, float]],
310    metric_names: Optional[List[str]] = None
311) -> Dict[str, Dict[str, float]]:
312    """
313    Compute robustness metrics comparing nominal vs perturbed performance.
314
315    Args:
316        nominal_performance: Performance metrics for nominal conditions
317        perturbed_performances: List of performance metrics under perturbations
318        metric_names: Optional list of metric names to analyze
319
320    Returns:
321        Dictionary of robustness metrics for each performance metric
322    """
323    if not perturbed_performances:
324        return {}
325
326    if metric_names is None:
327        metric_names = list(nominal_performance.keys())
328
329    robustness_metrics = {}
330
331    for metric_name in metric_names:
332        if metric_name not in nominal_performance:
333            continue
334
335        nominal_value = nominal_performance[metric_name]
336        perturbed_values = []
337
338        for perf in perturbed_performances:
339            if metric_name in perf:
340                perturbed_values.append(perf[metric_name])
341
342        if not perturbed_values:
343            continue
344
345        perturbed_array = np.array(perturbed_values)
346
347        # Compute robustness metrics
348        mean_deviation = float(np.mean(np.abs(perturbed_array - nominal_value)))
349        max_deviation = float(np.max(np.abs(perturbed_array - nominal_value)))
350        std_deviation = float(np.std(perturbed_array))
351
352        # Robustness index (inverse of relative deviation)
353        if abs(nominal_value) > 1e-12:
354            relative_deviation = mean_deviation / abs(nominal_value)
355            robustness_index = 1.0 / (1.0 + relative_deviation)
356        else:
357            robustness_index = 1.0 if mean_deviation < 1e-6 else 0.0
358
359        robustness_metrics[metric_name] = {
360            'mean_deviation': mean_deviation,
361            'max_deviation': max_deviation,
362            'std_deviation': std_deviation,
363            'robustness_index': float(robustness_index)
364        }
365
366    return robustness_metrics
367
368
369def compute_comprehensive_metrics(
370    states: np.ndarray,
371    controls: np.ndarray,
372    time_vector: np.ndarray,
373    reference_states: Optional[np.ndarray] = None,
374    reference_controls: Optional[np.ndarray] = None
375) -> Dict[str, Any]:
376    """
377    Compute comprehensive metrics for control system analysis.
378
379    Args:
380        states: State trajectory matrix
381        controls: Control signal vector
382        time_vector: Time vector
383        reference_states: Optional reference state trajectory
384        reference_controls: Optional reference control signals
385
386    Returns:
387        Dictionary containing comprehensive metrics
388    """
389    metrics = {}
390
391    # Basic state metrics
392    if len(states) > 0:
393        for i in range(states.shape[1]):
394            state_data = states[:, i]
395            metrics[f'state_{i}_metrics'] = compute_basic_metrics(state_data)
396
397    # Control metrics
398    if len(controls) > 0:
399        metrics['control_metrics'] = compute_control_metrics(controls, time_vector)
400
401    # Performance metrics vs reference
402    if reference_states is not None and len(reference_states) > 0:
403        if len(states) > 0 and states.shape == reference_states.shape:
404            for i in range(states.shape[1]):
405                metrics[f'state_{i}_performance'] = compute_performance_metrics(
406                    reference_states[:, i], states[:, i]
407                )
408
409    if reference_controls is not None and len(reference_controls) > 0:
410        if len(controls) == len(reference_controls):
411            metrics['control_performance'] = compute_performance_metrics(
412                reference_controls, controls
413            )
414
415    # Stability metrics
416    if len(states) > 0:
417        ref_state = reference_states[-1] if reference_states is not None else None
418        metrics['stability_metrics'] = compute_stability_metrics(states, ref_state)
419
420    return metrics

FunctionsÂ¶

Compute basic statistical metrics for data analysis.

Args: data: Input data array

Source CodeÂ¶

 1def compute_basic_metrics(data: np.ndarray) -> Dict[str, float]:
 2    """
 3    Compute basic statistical metrics for data analysis.
 4
 5    Args:
 6        data: Input data array
 7
 8    Returns:
 9        Dictionary containing basic statistical metrics
10    """
11    if len(data) == 0:
12        return {
13            'mean': 0.0,
14            'std': 0.0,
15            'min': 0.0,
16            'max': 0.0,
17            'median': 0.0,
18            'count': 0
19        }
20
21    return {
22        'mean': float(np.mean(data)),
23        'std': float(np.std(data)),
24        'min': float(np.min(data)),
25        'max': float(np.max(data)),
26        'median': float(np.median(data)),
27        'count': len(data)
28    }

compute_performance_metrics(reference, actual)Â¶

Compute performance metrics comparing actual vs reference data.

Args: reference: Reference/target data actual: Actual measured data

Returns: Dictionary containing performance metrics

Source CodeÂ¶

 1def compute_performance_metrics(
 2    reference: np.ndarray,
 3    actual: np.ndarray
 4) -> Dict[str, float]:
 5    """
 6    Compute performance metrics comparing actual vs reference data.
 7
 8    Args:
 9        reference: Reference/target data
10        actual: Actual measured data
11
12    Returns:
13        Dictionary containing performance metrics
14    """
15    if len(reference) != len(actual):
16        raise ValueError("Reference and actual data must have same length")
17
18    if len(reference) == 0:
19        return {'mse': 0.0, 'rmse': 0.0, 'mae': 0.0, 'max_error': 0.0}
20
21    error = actual - reference
22    mse = float(np.mean(error**2))
23    rmse = float(np.sqrt(mse))
24    mae = float(np.mean(np.abs(error)))
25    max_error = float(np.max(np.abs(error)))
26
27    return {
28        'mse': mse,
29        'rmse': rmse,
30        'mae': mae,
31        'max_error': max_error
32    }

compute_control_metrics(control_signals, time_vector)Â¶

Compute control-specific performance metrics.

Args: control_signals: Control input signals over time time_vector: Optional time vector for time-based metrics

Returns: Dictionary containing control metrics

Source CodeÂ¶

 1def compute_control_metrics(
 2    control_signals: np.ndarray,
 3    time_vector: Optional[np.ndarray] = None
 4) -> Dict[str, float]:
 5    """
 6    Compute control-specific performance metrics.
 7
 8    Args:
 9        control_signals: Control input signals over time
10        time_vector: Optional time vector for time-based metrics
11
12    Returns:
13        Dictionary containing control metrics
14    """
15    if len(control_signals) == 0:
16        return {
17            'control_effort': 0.0,
18            'max_control': 0.0,
19            'control_variation': 0.0,
20            'settling_time': 0.0
21        }
22
23    # Basic control metrics
24    control_effort = float(np.sum(np.abs(control_signals)))
25    max_control = float(np.max(np.abs(control_signals)))
26
27    # Control variation (total variation)
28    if len(control_signals) > 1:
29        control_variation = float(np.sum(np.abs(np.diff(control_signals))))
30    else:
31        control_variation = 0.0
32
33    # Settling time estimation (time to reach within 5% of final value)
34    settling_time = 0.0
35    if time_vector is not None and len(time_vector) == len(control_signals):
36        final_value = control_signals[-1]
37        tolerance = 0.05 * abs(final_value) if abs(final_value) > 1e-10 else 0.05
38
39        # Find last time control signal was outside tolerance
40        for i in range(len(control_signals) - 1, -1, -1):
41            if abs(control_signals[i] - final_value) > tolerance:
42                settling_time = float(time_vector[min(i + 1, len(time_vector) - 1)])
43                break
44
45    return {
46        'control_effort': control_effort,
47        'max_control': max_control,
48        'control_variation': control_variation,
49        'settling_time': settling_time
50    }

compute_stability_metrics(states, reference_state)Â¶

Compute stability-related metrics for state trajectories.

Args: states: State trajectory matrix (time x state_dim) reference_state: Optional reference state for deviation metrics

Returns: Dictionary containing stability metrics

Source CodeÂ¶

 1def compute_stability_metrics(
 2    states: np.ndarray,
 3    reference_state: Optional[np.ndarray] = None
 4) -> Dict[str, float]:
 5    """
 6    Compute stability-related metrics for state trajectories.
 7
 8    Args:
 9        states: State trajectory matrix (time x state_dim)
10        reference_state: Optional reference state for deviation metrics
11
12    Returns:
13        Dictionary containing stability metrics
14    """
15    if len(states) == 0:
16        return {
17            'max_deviation': 0.0,
18            'final_deviation': 0.0,
19            'stability_margin': 0.0,
20            'lyapunov_estimate': 0.0
21        }
22
23    if reference_state is None:
24        reference_state = np.zeros(states.shape[1])
25
26    # Deviation from reference
27    deviations = states - reference_state
28    deviation_norms = np.linalg.norm(deviations, axis=1)
29
30    # Handle NaN values gracefully (use nanmax to ignore NaN)
31    max_deviation = float(np.nanmax(deviation_norms))
32    final_deviation = float(np.nanmax([deviation_norms[-1], 0.0]))  # Handle NaN in final value
33
34    # If all values are NaN, return safe defaults
35    if np.isnan(max_deviation):
36        max_deviation = 0.0
37    if np.isnan(final_deviation):
38        final_deviation = 0.0
39
40    # Simple stability margin (inverse of max deviation)
41    stability_margin = 1.0 / (1.0 + max_deviation)
42
43    # Rough Lyapunov exponent estimate
44    lyapunov_estimate = 0.0
45    if len(deviation_norms) > 10:
46        # Use log of deviation growth
47        nonzero_deviations = deviation_norms[deviation_norms > 1e-12]
48        if len(nonzero_deviations) > 5:
49            log_deviations = np.log(nonzero_deviations)
50            if len(log_deviations) > 1:
51                lyapunov_estimate = float(np.mean(np.diff(log_deviations)))
52
53    return {
54        'max_deviation': max_deviation,
55        'final_deviation': final_deviation,
56        'stability_margin': stability_margin,
57        'lyapunov_estimate': lyapunov_estimate
58    }

compute_frequency_metrics(signal, sampling_rate, frequency_bands)Â¶

Compute frequency domain metrics for signal analysis.

Args: signal: Input signal sampling_rate: Sampling rate in Hz frequency_bands: Optional list of (low, high) frequency bands

Returns: Dictionary containing frequency domain metrics

Source CodeÂ¶

 1def compute_frequency_metrics(
 2    signal: np.ndarray,
 3    sampling_rate: float,
 4    frequency_bands: Optional[List[Tuple[float, float]]] = None
 5) -> Dict[str, Any]:
 6    """
 7    Compute frequency domain metrics for signal analysis.
 8
 9    Args:
10        signal: Input signal
11        sampling_rate: Sampling rate in Hz
12        frequency_bands: Optional list of (low, high) frequency bands
13
14    Returns:
15        Dictionary containing frequency domain metrics
16    """
17    if len(signal) < 2:
18        return {
19            'dominant_frequency': 0.0,
20            'bandwidth': 0.0,
21            'power_spectrum': np.array([]),
22            'frequencies': np.array([])
23        }
24
25    # Compute power spectral density
26    frequencies = np.fft.fftfreq(len(signal), 1/sampling_rate)
27    fft_signal = np.fft.fft(signal)
28    power_spectrum = np.abs(fft_signal)**2
29
30    # Only consider positive frequencies
31    positive_freq_idx = frequencies >= 0
32    frequencies = frequencies[positive_freq_idx]
33    power_spectrum = power_spectrum[positive_freq_idx]
34
35    # Find dominant frequency
36    if len(power_spectrum) > 0:
37        dominant_freq_idx = np.argmax(power_spectrum)
38        dominant_frequency = float(frequencies[dominant_freq_idx])
39    else:
40        dominant_frequency = 0.0
41
42    # Estimate bandwidth (90% power)
43    total_power = np.sum(power_spectrum)
44    cumulative_power = np.cumsum(power_spectrum)
45
46    if total_power > 0:
47        # Find frequencies where cumulative power is 5% and 95%
48        low_idx = np.argmax(cumulative_power >= 0.05 * total_power)
49        high_idx = np.argmax(cumulative_power >= 0.95 * total_power)
50        bandwidth = float(frequencies[high_idx] - frequencies[low_idx])
51    else:
52        bandwidth = 0.0
53
54    # Compute power in frequency bands if specified
55    band_power = {}
56    if frequency_bands:
57        for i, (low, high) in enumerate(frequency_bands):
58            band_mask = (frequencies >= low) & (frequencies <= high)
59            band_power[f'band_{i}_power'] = float(np.sum(power_spectrum[band_mask]))
60
61    result = {
62        'dominant_frequency': dominant_frequency,
63        'bandwidth': bandwidth,
64        'power_spectrum': power_spectrum,
65        'frequencies': frequencies,
66        **band_power
67    }
68
69    return result

compute_statistical_significance(data1, data2, test_type)Â¶

Compute statistical significance between two data sets.

Args: data1: First data set data2: Second data set test_type: Type of statistical test (â€˜ttestâ€™, â€˜mannwhitneyâ€™, â€˜ksâ€™)

Returns: Dictionary containing test statistics and p-value

Source CodeÂ¶

 1def compute_statistical_significance(
 2    data1: np.ndarray,
 3    data2: np.ndarray,
 4    test_type: str = 'ttest'
 5) -> Dict[str, float]:
 6    """
 7    Compute statistical significance between two data sets.
 8
 9    Args:
10        data1: First data set
11        data2: Second data set
12        test_type: Type of statistical test ('ttest', 'mannwhitney', 'ks')
13
14    Returns:
15        Dictionary containing test statistics and p-value
16    """
17    if len(data1) == 0 or len(data2) == 0:
18        return {'statistic': 0.0, 'p_value': 1.0, 'significant': False}
19
20    try:
21        if test_type == 'ttest':
22            statistic, p_value = stats.ttest_ind(data1, data2)
23        elif test_type == 'mannwhitney':
24            statistic, p_value = stats.mannwhitneyu(data1, data2, alternative='two-sided')
25        elif test_type == 'ks':
26            statistic, p_value = stats.ks_2samp(data1, data2)
27        else:
28            raise ValueError(f"Unknown test type: {test_type}")
29
30        significant = p_value < 0.05  # Standard significance level
31
32        return {
33            'statistic': float(statistic),
34            'p_value': float(p_value),
35            'significant': bool(significant)
36        }
37
38    except Exception as e:
39        warnings.warn(f"Statistical test failed: {e}")
40        return {'statistic': 0.0, 'p_value': 1.0, 'significant': False}

compute_robustness_metrics(nominal_performance, perturbed_performances, metric_names)Â¶

Compute robustness metrics comparing nominal vs perturbed performance.

Args: nominal_performance: Performance metrics for nominal conditions perturbed_performances: List of performance metrics under perturbations metric_names: Optional list of metric names to analyze

Returns: Dictionary of robustness metrics for each performance metric

Source CodeÂ¶

 1def compute_robustness_metrics(
 2    nominal_performance: Dict[str, float],
 3    perturbed_performances: List[Dict[str, float]],
 4    metric_names: Optional[List[str]] = None
 5) -> Dict[str, Dict[str, float]]:
 6    """
 7    Compute robustness metrics comparing nominal vs perturbed performance.
 8
 9    Args:
10        nominal_performance: Performance metrics for nominal conditions
11        perturbed_performances: List of performance metrics under perturbations
12        metric_names: Optional list of metric names to analyze
13
14    Returns:
15        Dictionary of robustness metrics for each performance metric
16    """
17    if not perturbed_performances:
18        return {}
19
20    if metric_names is None:
21        metric_names = list(nominal_performance.keys())
22
23    robustness_metrics = {}
24
25    for metric_name in metric_names:
26        if metric_name not in nominal_performance:
27            continue
28
29        nominal_value = nominal_performance[metric_name]
30        perturbed_values = []
31
32        for perf in perturbed_performances:
33            if metric_name in perf:
34                perturbed_values.append(perf[metric_name])
35
36        if not perturbed_values:
37            continue
38
39        perturbed_array = np.array(perturbed_values)
40
41        # Compute robustness metrics
42        mean_deviation = float(np.mean(np.abs(perturbed_array - nominal_value)))
43        max_deviation = float(np.max(np.abs(perturbed_array - nominal_value)))
44        std_deviation = float(np.std(perturbed_array))
45
46        # Robustness index (inverse of relative deviation)
47        if abs(nominal_value) > 1e-12:
48            relative_deviation = mean_deviation / abs(nominal_value)
49            robustness_index = 1.0 / (1.0 + relative_deviation)
50        else:
51            robustness_index = 1.0 if mean_deviation < 1e-6 else 0.0
52
53        robustness_metrics[metric_name] = {
54            'mean_deviation': mean_deviation,
55            'max_deviation': max_deviation,
56            'std_deviation': std_deviation,
57            'robustness_index': float(robustness_index)
58        }
59
60    return robustness_metrics

compute_comprehensive_metrics(states, controls, time_vector, reference_states, reference_controls)Â¶

Compute comprehensive metrics for control system analysis.

Args: states: State trajectory matrix controls: Control signal vector time_vector: Time vector reference_states: Optional reference state trajectory reference_controls: Optional reference control signals

Returns: Dictionary containing comprehensive metrics

Source CodeÂ¶

 1def compute_comprehensive_metrics(
 2    states: np.ndarray,
 3    controls: np.ndarray,
 4    time_vector: np.ndarray,
 5    reference_states: Optional[np.ndarray] = None,
 6    reference_controls: Optional[np.ndarray] = None
 7) -> Dict[str, Any]:
 8    """
 9    Compute comprehensive metrics for control system analysis.
10
11    Args:
12        states: State trajectory matrix
13        controls: Control signal vector
14        time_vector: Time vector
15        reference_states: Optional reference state trajectory
16        reference_controls: Optional reference control signals
17
18    Returns:
19        Dictionary containing comprehensive metrics
20    """
21    metrics = {}
22
23    # Basic state metrics
24    if len(states) > 0:
25        for i in range(states.shape[1]):
26            state_data = states[:, i]
27            metrics[f'state_{i}_metrics'] = compute_basic_metrics(state_data)
28
29    # Control metrics
30    if len(controls) > 0:
31        metrics['control_metrics'] = compute_control_metrics(controls, time_vector)
32
33    # Performance metrics vs reference
34    if reference_states is not None and len(reference_states) > 0:
35        if len(states) > 0 and states.shape == reference_states.shape:
36            for i in range(states.shape[1]):
37                metrics[f'state_{i}_performance'] = compute_performance_metrics(
38                    reference_states[:, i], states[:, i]
39                )
40
41    if reference_controls is not None and len(reference_controls) > 0:
42        if len(controls) == len(reference_controls):
43            metrics['control_performance'] = compute_performance_metrics(
44                reference_controls, controls
45            )
46
47    # Stability metrics
48    if len(states) > 0:
49        ref_state = reference_states[-1] if reference_states is not None else None
50        metrics['stability_metrics'] = compute_stability_metrics(states, ref_state)
51
52    return metrics

Usage ExamplesÂ¶

Compute All Metrics for a SimulationÂ¶

from src.benchmarks.metrics import compute_all_metrics
from src.simulation.engines.simulation_runner import run_simulation
from src.controllers.factory import create_smc_for_pso, SMCType
from src.plant.models.simplified import SimplifiedDynamics

# Run simulation
controller = create_smc_for_pso(SMCType.CLASSICAL, [10, 8, 15, 12, 50, 5])
dynamics = SimplifiedDynamics()

result = run_simulation(
    controller=controller,
    dynamics_model=dynamics,
    initial_state=[0.1, 0.05, 0, 0, 0, 0],
    sim_time=10.0,
    dt=0.01
)

# Compute comprehensive metrics
metrics = compute_all_metrics(
    t=result.time,
    x=result.states,
    u=result.control,
    max_force=100.0,
    include_advanced=True
)

# Access metrics
print("Control Performance:")
print(f"  ISE: {metrics['ise']:.4f}")
print(f"  ITAE: {metrics['itae']:.4f}")
print(f"  RMS Control: {metrics['rms_control']:.4f}")

print("
Stability Analysis:")
print(f"  Settling Time: {metrics['settling_time']:.3f}s")
print(f"  Overshoot: {metrics['overshoot']:.2f}%")
print(f"  Damping Ratio: {metrics['damping_ratio']:.3f}")

print("
Constraint Violations:")
print(f"  Saturation Count: {metrics['saturation_count']}")
print(f"  Saturation Severity: {metrics['saturation_severity']:.4f}")

Individual Metric ComputationÂ¶

from src.benchmarks.metrics.control_metrics import compute_ise, compute_itae
from src.benchmarks.metrics.stability_metrics import compute_overshoot, compute_settling_time
from src.benchmarks.metrics.constraint_metrics import count_control_violations

# Control metrics
ise = compute_ise(result.time, result.states)
itae = compute_itae(result.time, result.states)

# Stability metrics
overshoot = compute_overshoot(result.states[:, 0])  # First angle
settling_time = compute_settling_time(result.time, result.states, threshold=0.02)

# Constraint violations
violations, severity, peak = count_control_violations(result.control, max_force=100.0)

print(f"ISE: {ise:.4f}, ITAE: {itae:.4f}")
print(f"Overshoot: {overshoot:.2f}%, Settling: {settling_time:.3f}s")
print(f"Violations: {violations}, Severity: {severity:.4f}, Peak: {peak:.2f}")

Custom Metric: Chattering IndexÂ¶

import numpy as np

def compute_chattering_index(u, dt):
    """Quantify control chattering."""
    # Total variation of control signal
    tv = np.sum(np.abs(np.diff(u))) * dt
    return tv

chattering = compute_chattering_index(result.control, dt=0.01)
print(f"Chattering Index: {chattering:.4f}")

# Compare chattering across controllers
controllers = {
    'Classical': create_smc_for_pso(SMCType.CLASSICAL, [10, 8, 15, 12, 50, 5]),
    'STA': create_smc_for_pso(SMCType.SUPER_TWISTING, [25, 10, 15, 12, 20, 15]),
}

chattering_results = {}
for name, ctrl in controllers.items():
    result = run_simulation(ctrl, dynamics, [0.1, 0.05, 0, 0, 0, 0], 10.0, 0.01)
    chattering_results[name] = compute_chattering_index(result.control, 0.01)

for name, ci in chattering_results.items():
    print(f"{name} Chattering: {ci:.4f}")

Energy-Based MetricsÂ¶

# example-metadata:
# runnable: false

# Track energy conservation (for unforced natural dynamics)
def compute_energy_drift(result, dynamics):
    """Measure energy drift as validation check."""
    energies = [dynamics.compute_total_energy(x) for x in result.states]
    initial_energy = energies[0]
    drift = np.abs(np.array(energies) - initial_energy) / initial_energy * 100
    max_drift = np.max(drift)
    mean_drift = np.mean(drift)
    return {'max_drift_%': max_drift, 'mean_drift_%': mean_drift}

energy_metrics = compute_energy_drift(result, dynamics)
print(f"Energy drift: {energy_metrics['max_drift_%']:.3f}% (max), "
      f"{energy_metrics['mean_drift_%']:.3f}% (mean)")

Batch Metric Computation for TrialsÂ¶

from src.benchmarks.metrics import compute_all_metrics

# Compute metrics for multiple trials
trials_results = []  # List of simulation results from multiple runs

metrics_collection = []
for result in trials_results:
    metrics = compute_all_metrics(result.time, result.states, result.control, 100.0)
    metrics_collection.append(metrics)

# Aggregate statistics
import pandas as pd
df = pd.DataFrame(metrics_collection)

print("Metric Statistics Across Trials:")
print(df[['ise', 'settling_time', 'overshoot', 'rms_control']].describe())

See: ../../../performance_metrics/metric_definitions
